content: Hi. Studying and following rustc development is my new hobby. I hope to some day be of help! In the meantime I'll read code, scratch my head and hopefully learn :)
you can ping me if you need an issue to work on :slight_smile:

@DPC sure it would help me learn faster if I was tasked with a specific issue. My impression is that the project wants more hands working on tech debt issues. I think that type of work would be a great resource for learning the code base.
I mean: as opposed to developing new features
ah okay. It is just that there are small things left to be done on various issues and I feel it's a good way to get started. This aren't about new features, they are about polishing old ones xD
Sure, anything that you feel can get a newcomer started :slight_smile:
meanwhile you can also look at the working groups (each one has their own "stream" here) and see if anything interests you :slight_smile:

Well, what got me especially interested in the compiler in the first place is async/await. This feature being released made us choose rust for a project at work last year. But we had a couple of ergonomics issues, and I started reading through a lot of github issues to see if those things are already reported. I realized I need to have at least a high level understanding of the code base in order to fully understand bug descriptions reported by experienced members. So I read through the rustc dev guide, watched all of the async interviews. Now I'm here :)
Sadly async/await is fairly undocumented in the dev guide, but feel free to ask if you have any questions as to how it works
@Jonas Schievink actually I've been reading many of your recent PRs, that's a great learning resource!

Jonas Schievink said:

Sadly async/await is fairly undocumented in the dev guide, but feel free to ask if you have any questions as to how it works

Right, this is something we should improve. Maybe when the Overview is done? :slight_smile:
